target_text: "It is difficult to define and measure. That’s for sure. I think before agile, there was a great focus on product level quality. Mainly free of defects and meets customer’s needs. I saw in agile a shift toward code quality and a design that responds to change. There is also a continuous improvement of the process effort."

Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a master’s in Geography, I approach spatial-economic questions through a pragmatic lens, prioritizing actionable insights for decision-making. My research interest in Economics steers me toward regional development, market accessibility, and place-based policy evaluation, often privileging quantitative, GIS-enabled evidence. I recognize my epistemological assumptions—positivist-leaning and optimization-oriented—which may undervalue lived experience and alternative ontologies. The way questions are framed and how users respond guide my sampling, coding, and model choices, potentially amplifying dominant stakeholder voices. By foregrounding reflexivity and triangulation, I seek to balance efficiency with equity and contextual nuance in interpreting results.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing bachelor’s-level study in statistics, I bring computational problem-solving and data-driven habits to economic inquiry. My research goal is to produce reproducible, statistically rigorous analyses that inform practical economic decisions. I recognize that my cultural background, personal experiences, and a developer’s efficiency mindset can bias variable selection, model choice, and preference for quantifiable outcomes. To mitigate this, I triangulate methods, document assumptions, and invite critique. The question and user responses further shape my framing, operationalization, and interpretation, prompting reflexive checks that align my methods with the study’s context and stakeholders’ perspectives.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a master’s-level inquiry, bringing a computational mindset to anthropological questions. Guided by anthropology (QS) and research interests in economics (NSF), I aim to examine how digital infrastructures mediate economic behavior and inequality. My practice is shaped by ethical and societal assumptions—valuing fairness, privacy, open access, and sometimes technological solutionism—which I interrogate through reflexivity. The framing of the Question and the User’s Response directs my attention to certain categories and language, potentially privileging measurable patterns over lived meanings. Consequently, my interpretations may foreground systems, incentives, and data, while I strive to center participant voices and cultural context.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Qualitative SE Researcher (Doctoral; CS–Software Engineering; NSF interests: Human-Centered/Sociotechnical SE, metrics); Biases: constructivist, metric-skeptical, pro-adaptability

codebook.justification: From a constructivist SE lens, [It is difficult to define and measure.] underscores contested construct validity and metric indeterminacy.
As a qualitative SE doctoral researcher, [a shift toward code quality] denotes value-laden reweighting of evaluation criteria over time.
Through a sociotechnical lens, [a design that responds to change] foregrounds subjective judgments of adaptability and architectural resilience.
Grounded in HCC/SE values, [continuous improvement of the process] reflects iterative learning cultures resistant to single, objective benchmarks.

Role_init_codebook.role: Interpretivist Software Engineering Researcher (PhD; CS/IS; Agile & socio-technical; reflexive pro-agile bias)

codebook.justification: The text flags measurement indeterminacy: [It is difficult to define and measure.]. As an interpretivist SE PhD, I treat 'quality' as socially constructed rather than fixed.
This frames quality as conformance and fitness-for-use: [free of defects and meets customer’s needs]. From a software engineering lens, I code this as product-centric value criteria.
The author signals a paradigmatic reorientation: [a shift toward code quality]. Through an agile-methods focus, I foreground maintainability and readability as evaluative heuristics.
Quality is extended to processual refinement: [continuous improvement of the process effort]. From a socio-technical stance, I treat this as kaizen-oriented capability, not an objective metric.

Role_init_codebook.role: Qualitative Software Engineering Researcher (PhD Candidate; QS: Computer Science & Information Systems; NSF: Human-Centered Computing/Software Engineering; Reflexivity: pro‑agile, interpretivist, process- and user-value bias)

codebook.justification: Anchored by [It is difficult to define and measure.], quality is positioned as an indeterminate construct requiring interpretive judgment. My interpretivist, pro‑agile SE lens foregrounds ambiguity as analytically salient.
Framed by [meets customer’s needs], I privilege experiential value over defect counts, aligning with HCI/SE concerns. This reflects my NSF-aligned focus on user value in socio-technical systems.

From [a design that responds to change], adaptability is treated as a normative quality attribute under agile epistemology. This coding embeds my bias that evolvability is central to software quality.

Grounded in [continuous improvement of the process effort], I read a Kaizen-like orientation toward process capability. My process-centric stance (QS: CS/IS) interprets improvement as a core, yet subjective, quality dimension.

Agreed.definition: Quality is acknowledged as hard to pin down and quantify, as indicated by [It is difficult to define and measure.], signaling contested definition and measurement.
Quality involves ongoing refinement of how work is done, grounded in [continuous improvement of the process effort].
Under agile, evaluation moved toward internal code attributes, supported by [a shift toward code quality].

Disagreed.definition: Emphasizes user value ([meets customer’s needs]) over conformance/defect counts; diverges by privileging experiential outcomes rather than product defect status (focus difference).
Frames quality as defect absence ([free of defects]); diverges by prioritizing conformance/defect metrics over customer outcomes (emphasis mismatch with customer-centric reading).

Highlights adaptability at the architectural/design level ([a design that responds to change]); diverges from a code-centric reading of agile quality by shifting the locus of quality from code to design (granularity/focus difference).

disagree_explain:
Disagreement centers on three emphases: (1) Customer-Centric Quality vs Product-Level Conformance—some roles privilege [meets customer’s needs], others emphasize [free of defects]. (2) Code vs Design locus—one reading spotlights [a shift toward code quality], another highlights [a design that responds to change]. (3) These splits are sustained by acknowledged ambiguity: [It is difficult to define and measure.], enabling different interpretive frames across roles.
**Click on the option under Disagreed Items on the left to start the discussion**

Closing.definition: All roles agree the passage pairs free-of-defects with meets-customer-needs as co-equal aims, then shifts focus to code quality, adaptive design, and process improvement. It never privileges customer value over defect counts, so the Customer-Centric Quality code does not fit.

Use this code when quality is framed as product-level conformance, especially defect absence (free of defects), rather than customer outcomes. It cleanly distinguishes conformance-oriented statements from mentions of code quality, adaptability of design, or process continuous improvement.

Retain: the source explicitly mentions 'a design that responds to change,' distinguishing a design-level adaptability focus from concurrent code-level quality and earlier product-level quality. Preserving this code maintains granularity, reduces conflation across levels, and improves annotation precision.

Codebook.definition: Quality is acknowledged as hard to pin down and quantify, as indicated by [It is difficult to define and measure.], signaling contested definition and measurement.
Quality involves ongoing refinement of how work is done, grounded in [continuous improvement of the process effort].
Under agile, evaluation moved toward internal code attributes, supported by [a shift toward code quality].
